body: Is there a particular reason this can't be in Rust?

Yes, I believe this should all largely be written in rust rather than in C (other signal handlers are already written in rust). I'm also hesitant to land _linux-only_ support for this feature. I would much rather implement everything in one sweep than be in a confusing state for awhile while we're waiting on the next few patches.

I wrote it in C since I don't find bindings for signal things. I see there's some in libnative (why are those there?), but that's still missing sigaltstack, SIGSTKSZ, stack_t, siginfo_t.si_addr.

Isn't rust-bindgen good enough to handle system headers?

I'm fine with making this Linux-only for now, as I prefer things to be in
tree when possible to reduce rebase pain.
On Aug 9, 2014 8:50 PM, "Alex Crichton" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Yes, I believe this should all largely be written in rust rather than in C
> (other signal handlers are already written in rust). I'm also hesitant to
> land _linux-only_ support for this feature. I would much rather implement
> everything in one sweep than be in a confusing state for awhile while we're
> waiting on the next few patches.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/16388#issuecomment-51705431.
This works on Linux and OS X now.

I'll try to take a closer look at this soon (sadly not before next week), but how much of an effort do you think this will be to extend this strategy to windows? I would hate to commit to a unix-only design only to find out later that it isn't compatible with windows for one reason or another. You may also want to download the arm/android toolchain as you should be able to just tweak a `static` here or there to get support. If you have a list of missing statics as well, I can look those up for you.

This should be simpler on Windows (with the exception of green threads which would need the same handling as Unix). However it Windows does not install guard pages on threads created by CreateThread, nor will it call the vectored exception handler I installed. I think we're doing something bad in the runtime somewhere (excluding writing to fs:0x14).

Also, can you add tests for all the functionality added here? You should be able to just spawn a subprocess and then inspect the output to ensure that the handlers were triggered correctly. Some tests that should be written:
- Native overflow in C code
- Green overflow in C code
- Native segfault (not an overflow)
- Green segfault (not an overflow)

You can ignore the test for unimplemented platforms for now.

Another idea I thought of today is that you may be able to remove a good portion of the guard page logic by using `stack::get_sp_limit() + stack::RED_ZONE` for testing whether a fault is near a guard page or not.

I've done most of the suggested changed here and added (broken) Windows support.

I did not reuse the `stack_exhausted` function. The error messages does not inspect errno. I did not add a green overflow test (it would fail on Windows for some unknown reason) or the segfault tests since I'm not sure how to write those.

The following tests fail on Windows which I suspect is unrelated:
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/lint-group-plugin.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/lint-plugin-cmdline.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/lint-plugin.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/macro-crate-does-hygiene-work.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/macro-crate-outlive-expansion-phase.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/macro-crate.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/phase-syntax-link-does-resolve.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/syntax-extension-fourcc.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/syntax-extension-hexfloat.rs
    [run-pass] run-pass-fulldeps/syntax-extension-with-dll-deps.rs

OS X tests get stuck after test::abort_no_kill_runtime. All tests passes on Linux.

The tests fails on Windows at d398eb76ae5fdb7c08bbb7c0e3d85dc22d42c5ce too, so I'll assume I didn't break any of them.

What should I do about using `last_os_error`? How can I only borrow the current task (so I could call `stack_exhausted`)?
Ping @alexcrichton. What's the next step on this?

I'd like some tips on reproducing the failure on `try-linux`. My test passes locally (on Windows, OS X and Debian).

I think I should also just ignore libgreen, since that can never work on Windows.
And we're removing libgreen anyways, so ignoring it could work.

@Zoxc I'm sorry about being slow on this, please feel free to ping me on IRC with any questions if I'm too sluggish to respond here!

---

> I've done most of the suggested changed here and added (broken) Windows support.

Do you know what the next steps are for getting full Windows support?

> The error messages does not inspect errno

That's probably ok, so long as failure is caught and handled the error messages can always be improved later on.

> How can I only borrow the current task (so I could call `stack_exhausted`)?

Would `Local::borrow()` work here?

> I did not add a green overflow test

Given the current status of libgreen, I think that's ok.

> or the segfault tests since I'm not sure how to write those.

I was just thinking something like `*(0 as *mut int) = 1;` to trigger a segfault and make sure it doesn't print that the stack overflowed.

> I'd like some tips on reproducing the failure on `try-linux`.

Feel free to ping me on IRC to push this to try, does this need to be pushed as-is?

Locally I have one test failure:

```
failures:

---- [run-pass] run-pass/out-of-stack-no-split.rs stdout ----

        error: test run failed!
        status: exit code: 101
        command: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/test/run-pass/out-of-stack-no-split.stage2-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu 
        stdout:
        ------------------------------------------

        ------------------------------------------
        stderr:
        ------------------------------------------
        task '<main>' failed at 'assertion failed: error.as_slice().contains("has overflowed its stack")', /home/alex/code/rust4/src/test/run-pass/out-of-stack-no-split.rs:43

        ------------------------------------------

        task '[run-pass] run-pass/out-of-stack-no-split.rs' failed at 'explicit failure', /home/alex/code/rust4/src/compiletest/runtest.rs:1436



failures:
    [run-pass] run-pass/out-of-stack-no-split.rs

test result: FAILED. 7 passed; 1 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured

task '<main>' failed at 'Some tests failed', /home/alex/code/rust4/src/compiletest/compiletest.rs:257
make: *** [tmp/check-stage2-T-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu-H-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu-rpass.ok] Error 101
```

Right before the test failed the machine was swapping like crazy, and I'm not entirely sure what was happening.

I've moved the error message reporting into it's own function. The code is using `Local::try_unsafe_borrow` now so it doesn't change the `Task` object anymore.

The failure of `out-of-stack-no-split.rs` on Ubuntu 14.04 x86_64 is not introduced by this patch so I have added Linux on the ignore list there. It turns out that the main thread stack is allocated to 74 TB when executed by with `make check` (the test passes when run manually). This leads to the OOM killer killing the process for `out-of-stack-no-split.rs` and leading to a test failure. This does not happen on Arch Linux x86_64 and Debian Jessie x86_64.
Awesome work @Zoxc! I think this is just about ready to go. Just a few more small nits and I'll hand this over to bors.
This passes tests on try now (with the exception of BSD, which I hopefully fixed)
I see you test for Android too, so I added (untested) support for it.
All Android test fails with `error: undefined reference to 'signal'`. Any idea what's missing?
I'm just disabling Android for now. We can fix that later.

Sure, we can land this for now with android disabled. Could you open an issue on enabling for android @Zoxc?

FYI this is the definition in the header file:

``` c
extern __sighandler_t bsd_signal(int, __sighandler_t);          

/* the default is bsd */                                        
static __inline__ __sighandler_t signal(int s, __sighandler_t f)
{                                                               
    return bsd_signal(s,f);                                     
}                                                               
```
